awd_titl_txt: CRII: ACI: Algorithms and Tools to Facilitate the Development of High Fidelity Reactive Molecular Dynamics Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Atomistic simulations enable understanding, analysis, and design of complex systems at spatio-temporal scales not easily accessible to experimental observation. Conventional molecular dynamics techniques have been applied with great success in application domains ranging from materials design to biophysical systems. Recent developments in reactive molecular dynamics have significantly extended the application scope of these techniques to systems that involve chemical bond activity. The core of these reactive atomistic simulations is a model for atomic interactions that describes the chemical structure of the domain, as well as its time evolution. This project aims to build a cyberinfrastructure to facilitate the development of highly resolved models of atomic interactions, along with their associated parameterizations. It will accomplish these goals through novel algorithms and software tools, reference datasets, and comprehensive validation in diverse application domains. The resulting infrastructure can enable computational scientists to develop high fidelity reactive force fields in a time and cost effective way. As a result, the accuracy and scope of reactive atomistic simulations have the potential to be increased significantly. The intellectual contributions of the project are complemented by education and outreach efforts that focus on interdisciplinary education through development and dissemination of instructional modules, publications, and presentations. Outreach efforts focus on recruitment of underrepresented minorities at the graduate level, and integration of undergraduate students into research efforts at an early stage.  Therefore, this research aligns with the NSF mission to promote the progress of science and to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.

This project focuses on algorithms and software for the development and optimization of force fields for reactive molecular dynamics (MD) techniques. The fidelity of these simulations is critically dependent on the functional forms and parameterizations of the inter-atomic potentials. Traditionally, the development of inter-atomic potentials has involved significant domain expertise, and is highly time and labor-intensive. This project aims to design a powerful new cyberinfrastructure that integrates extraction of reference datasets, model selection and optimization algorithms, and comprehensive validation, to enable rapid prototyping and deployment of complex reactive atomistic models. In particular, reference datasets are selected for coverage as well as their impact on the inter-atomic potential, using novel procedures to minimize the requirements on quantum mechanical screenings. The process of optimizing the force field leverages this reference set and introduces a histogram based optimization technique for parameter sampling and selection. Finally, a novel API is proposed to enable the translation of suitable force fields from high-level mathematical descriptions into efficient parallel software. By automating each labor-intensive step along the way, the proposed framework aims to form a first-of-its-kind environment for development of high fidelity reactive MD models. Given the applicability of reactive MD models from materials modeling to biophysical simulations, the proposed cyberinfrastructure can help advance the state-of-the-art in advance materials design and drug discovery.

por.por_cntn:
The main focus in this project has been the creation of an integrated force field development and optimization framework for reactive molecular dynamics (RMD) models. A force field is essentially a set of parameterized mathematical equations that describe interactions between atoms in a given molecular system. RMD methods fill an important gap in the computational landscape of molecular modeling as they enable simulations of reactive systems while avoiding the computational expense of electronic structure methods. As such RMD models have a wide scope of applications in materials science, chemistry and biology. While reactive MD models are used by thousands of researchers worldwide, only a small fraction of those are involved in the development of force fields due to the level of expertise and amount of work required in doing so. In this project, the PI and his research team has developed new algorithms and tools, and leveraaged existing software in novel ways to reduce the barrier of entry into the task of reactive force field development.

The major outcome of this project is the Automated Force Field Fitting (AF3) Framework. AF3 comprises two main parts, a training structure database (TSD) and a genetic algorithm based force field optimization component. Regarding the first part, we have developed an auto-generation scheme for the force field training structure database (TSD) and the corresponding reference data. A training structure database is a (relatively small) collection of atoms representing the key properties of the molecular/material system of interest. We established a novel protocol that derives training data structures from three different categories: i) Simple molecular and crystal structures, ii) complex structures, iii) amorphous formations. Within each category, perturbation of atom positions & bonds allows us to generate a wide selection of structures with a good coverage of the molecular/material properties. Given the number of elements in the training dataset and the cost of accurately calculating their electronic structure properties (using Density Functional Theory, DFT, or Coupled Cluster, CC), we setup a high throughput screening infrastructure using the Fireworks program. For the optimization of the force field, the ogolem software is used which provides a wide variety of features for genetic optimization of force field parameters. We have streamlined the interface between the automated TSD component and ogolem so that newly generated training datasets can be easily imported into ogolem for force field optimization.

We used the AF3 framework to develop optimized Reax force fields (ReaxFF) for Li-O systems. Lithium metal has the highest capacity of any lithium-ion battery anode material, and it can dramatically increase energy and power density of batteries. A good reactive force field would be expected to predict the experimentally known brittle fracture property of a Li-O slab. However, existing ReaxFF parameter sets for Li-O predict ductile fracture as opposed to a brittle one. We have trained a new ReaxFF model for Li-O using the AF3 framework. The resulting Reax model better demonstrates the brittle structure of the Li-O slab compared to the original model.

An important enabler of the above results with Li-O slab has been efficient solvers for charge distribution models. Charge models are indispensable to reactive molecular dynamics because a reaction is effectively a charge transfer between atoms. Linear solvers for charge models that are used to dynamically determine atom polarizations constitute significant bottlenecks in terms of time-to-solution and the overall scalability of RMD simulations. A side outcome of this project has been numerical methods to accelerate the iterative solvers used for several charge models. These solvers have been made publicly available as part of the PuReMD software that is being developed by the PI's team.

This project has provided resources to fund the training of two graduate students (Kurt O'Hearn and Abdullah Alperen) who were trained in cutting edge research at the intersection of computer science, computational chemistry and materials science.

This project has resulted in significant sicientific output. We published a workshop paper ("Towards fast scalable solvers for charge equilibration in molecular dynamics applications", 7th Workshop on Latest Advances in Scalable Algorithms for Large-Scale Systems (ScalA)) and a research article at the International Journal of High Performance Computing Applications ("Optimizing the performance of reactive molecular dynamics simulations for many-core architectures", IJHPCA 33 (2), 304-321). Both of these publications are peer-reviewed. We also have a paper in revision for potential publication at the SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing; this paper is on acceleration of charge model solvers. We have another paper in preparation for submission to a computational chemistry journal; the focus of this article will be on the new ReaxFF model we are developing for Li-O materials.

We have also disseminated our findings through presentations at the Old Dominion University, University of Michigan, SIAM CSE confereces, as well as several research meetings within Michigan State University.
